title: Should I create timely content or evergreen content? - Quora

response.answer_text: Do you want to know the secret behind building a blog that gets backlinks, ranks for important keywords and receives tons of organic traffic over time? Two words: evergreen content. These two words are the backbone of our strategy here at Ahrefs. It’s how we’ve grown our blog from 15,000 visitors/month to >200,000 visitors/month:  Why is evergreen content important? When Donald Trump won the election in 2016, the New York Times reported it.  Because they were one of the first few to break the news, their site saw a massive spike in traffic. But that only lasted for a couple of months. As people started coming to terms with Donald Trump’s win, they were no longer interested in the topic of “Donald Trump winning the election.” As such, traffic to that article plummeted. Every time you publish this kind of post, and it gets widely shared, you get an initial burst of traffic. We call that the “spike of hope.” Over time, as interest wanes, this quickly degenerates into a “flatline of nope.”  This puts you on the hamster wheel of content creation. You have to keep publishing. Once you stop, your traffic will drop. And that’s precisely why you should create evergreen content around evergreen topics. It helps you: Do less work. You don’t have to change or update the content often, which saves time.Get regular organic traffic. Google’s job is to provide answers to people’s queries. If the content is out‐of‐date, it won’t rank. Creating evergreen content is your best bet if you want to attract organic traffic to your post month after month, year after year, and not see a decline in traffic after a month or two.This is what we do at Ahrefs. We never cover news, fads or controversial issues that people won’t care about next week. We only target evergreen topics and do everything in our power to create content that is as evergreen as possible. Learn how to create evergreen content in this post here.

This is a great question. One I think many bloggers and marketers alike don’t consider enough. But I don’t think the answer is as simple to answer using one or the other. Instead you have to look at all the factors before making a decision. The first factor being your budget. Currently, about 29% of marketing budgets are used for content marketing. This means if a businesses budget is $10,000 then they are spending $2,900 on content marketing. You can see the graph below to see how this breaks down even more for B2B.  Is your budget the average? Can you spend more? Or do you need to allocate less to marketing? Knowing where you stand will help you determine how much content you can comfortably put out each week, month, year etc. Once you know that you need to consider your audience. You will know best what articles are working for your audience. If you don’t look to your analytics to see the articles that are getting the most views. If you are a very new business and don’t have this data look to the data from others. There is a graphic from Ascend2, which I find very useful. It breaks down the most effective vs. most difficult kind of content. Allowing you to see where you should spend most of your time.  If you notice that your most popular articles are those that are timely in nature, focus on that. If you see evergreen content being the top choice go that direction. But if you have the budget, I find there is value in both types of content. My website focuses on putting out both evergreen and timely content, to help meet the needs of our consumers as a whole. Of course that isn’t possible for every company. But if you take my advice to heart you should be able to discover which will work best for your business. I hope I helped answer your question! If you want to know any more about content marketing or its benefits I highly recommend this article Stealth Marketing: The Art of Content Marketing | MarTechExec

I use both evergreen and timely content, but the publishing channel makes a difference. Time-sensitive material is best distributed through email or social media. If my client is exhibiting at a trade show, for instance, we’ll produce content for eNewsletters, direct mail, email blasts, Twitter, or LinkedIn related to the products they will exhibit at the event. A call to action for this messaging might be scheduling personal product demonstrations at the show. We use social media to publish and promote evergreen content as well. Repeat promotional posts for eBooks, guides, online calculators, or customer case studies regularly, perhaps changing headlines or graphics. I advise my clients to avoid posting time-sensitive content to their web sites, unless included as a live Twitter feed or similar method. Website maintenance is a task frequently postponed, and timely content doesn’t get deleted or updated as it should. Displaying old information makes a poor impression on the visitors clients have worked hard to attract. Many of my clients are in the mailing business so we recommend they refer to customer benefits such as postage savings as percentages rather than dollars. Otherwise, their web sites are immediately out of date when postage rates change.

When comparing timely content vs evergreen content it’s like you’re putting a sprint and a marathon face to face. It’s not about which types of evergreen content or topical info is good and which is bad, but it’s a matter of merging. Give yourself the treat of short-term buzz and long-term outcome, both promising to provide conversions and hype. Experiment with both, check out the ideas and examples tackled above, and see how each one works for you in terms of results (which one drives traffic for you). And don’t forget: if you’re after more consistent posting and bringing in followers back to your site, use topical content, and if you seek to build up the pillars that give you better SEO results and a chance to reach out to new readers, also use evergreen blog posts. Opt for a hybrid model: get the best of both worlds and include evergreen and seasonal content in your digital marketing strategy. Also, never forget that content, be it evergreen, topical or timely, must be promoted properly! Share your content on social media and even promote it with ads. Most of the times, it’s not enough to just write content and publish it.

Unless you’re in the news business or commentary on anything news-related, you’ll want to focus on evergreen. A business who is selling products or services will see a greater benefit and see a much higher return on investment in content if that content can live on and serve their audience (target customers) well for a longer stretch of time / indefinitely. Simple as that.

I say it depends on why you’re publishing the content. What purpose will it serve? You’ll find you’ll need a mix of timely and evergreen content. But in the end, if anything’s going to stick around longer than 30 days or so, it needs to be relevant beyond that time. That doesn’t mean you need to get rid of everything that was topical then but isn’t now. Simply update it to emphasize a particular point that doesn’t lose relevance for readers, while keeping the historical context.

Actually, most often you should aim to make your content timely and evergreen at the same time. How to achieve that? By taking a timely subject and adding evergreen background to it. The timely part could be an example or case study to the evergreen concept. That way, you get the best of both - content that has the potential to become hot, but won’t die down once the fuss is over. Have a look at this article: 6 marketing lessons. In honor of Steve Jobs. It takes a timely matter (Steve Job’s death) and wraps it in an evergreen value (marketing lessons).
That depends on what niche you have selected. Also, you should create a mix of both type of contents to last long and to build a brand in long term.
Timely content vs evergreen content - i would choose evergreen content. This would take time but the result can be amazing.

Both, actually. A debate around which content is better to use is artificial, since most marketers understand the advantage of a hybrid approach and they try to maintain the ratio between evergreen and topical publications that works best for them.
It should include both , you can always revisit the timely content, edit them if these are related to any industry updates. Study the metrics - what does your audience like more.
